G. TEMPORARY MINING OPERATION
1. The application for a temporary mining operation to be constructed prior to the
development of a subdivision can be submitted after the approval of a subdivision
concept plan for the site.
2.
The location of the excavation sites must correspond to the stormwater facilities
and/or lakes or ponds on the approved concept plan.
9-44

3. The first one hundred (100) feet of the access entry road from a public street must

ARTICLE 10 - DEVELOPMENT STANDARDS
SECTION 10.1: FENCE STANDARDS
A. The following requirements shall apply to fences in residential zoning districts and
does not apply to bona fide farms:
1. Electric or Barbed Wire Fences
a. Fences shall be identified with signs or flags if within three (3) feet of a
property line;
b. Any electrical or barbed wire fence shall be located on the interior side of the
lot.
SECTION 10.2: SOLID WASTE COLLECTION AND STORAGE
A. APPLICABILITY
1. The following requirements of this Section shall apply to solid waste collection
and storage areas on Major or Minor Site Plans.
B. REQUIREMENTS
1. Solid waste collection and storage areas shall be provided for all nonresidential
uses, as well as all multi-family and mobile-home park developments where each
unit is not provided with individual solid waste collection service.
2. Solid waste collection and storage areas shall be designed and sized to
accommodate the reasonably expected amount of solid waste generated by the
associated use.
3. All nonresidential and communal residential solid waste collection and storage
areas shall be screened in accordance with the standards of Section 10.8 (Site
Feature Screening) and shall be located a minimum of twenty-five (25) feet from
any external property line.
SECTION 10.3: MAIL DELIVERY FACILITIES (CLUSTER BOXES)
A. Where the United States Postal Service determines that communal mail delivery is
required, shared mailbox facilities shall be installed by the owner in such locations
and in such manner as determined by the USPS. Communal mailbox facilities shall
have at least one off-street parking space provided at the facility when it is designed
to serve ten (10) or more residences, in accordance with the Onslow County
Subdivision Ordinance.
SECTION 10.4: OUTDOOR STORAGE AREAS
A. The following requirements of this Section shall apply to outdoor storage areas on
Major or Minor Site Plans:
1. The outdoor storage of construction materials, debris, inoperable equipment,
vehicles, boats or similar items shall be prohibited within fifty (50) feet of a street
right-of-way or property line, unless such outdoor storage area is concealed by an
opaque fence.
SECTION 10.5: OUTDOOR LIGHTING
A. APPLICABILITY
1. Outdoor lighting is optional.
2. When outdoor lighting is proposed, the following standards shall apply for
purposes other than single-family or two-family residences.
10-1

B. SHIELDING REQUIRED
1. All outdoor lighting shall be shielded to prevent glare from trespassing onto
adjacent properties, adjacent streets, or otherwise create a nuisance or safety
hazard.
2. All outdoor lighting shall be downward facing, and/or arranged or shielded as to:
a. Not cast light above an imaginary line drawn at the top of the light to avoid
negatively impacting air traffic whether commercial or private from Albert J.
Ellis Airport or airstrips, and/or military flights from the Marine Base Camp
Lejeune or Marine Air Station New River.
b. Avoid casting light upon adjacent properties and streets; and
C. Avoid casting light into the right-of-way creating a hazard for motor vehicles
and/or pedestrians.
C. PARKING LOT LIGHTING STANDARDS
1. Parking lot lighting fixtures shall not exceed thirty (30) feet in height and shall
utilize full cut-off type fixtures.
D. BUILDING MOUNTED LIGHTING
1. Building mounted lighting fixtures may not be used to illuminate parking areas.
All building mounted lighting fixtures shall be directed downward to light
adjacent pedestrian areas, or to provide architectural accent lighting.
E. GROUND MOUNTED LIGHTING
1. Ground mounted light fixtures may be used to illuminate architectural features on
buildings, pedestrian walkways, and landscaping fixtures, provided that the lights
are directed toward the feature that they are illuminating and do not constitute a
safety hazard for motorists on adjacent streets or in parking areas.
2. In no case shall the illumination of entire building walls with high intensity
spotlights be permitted.

i. The installation of plant material required to be installed for the purpose of
landscaping, buffering, or screening, may be deferred until the next
appropriate planting season with the approval of the Zoning
Administrator. In the event that the owner or developer fails to install
the required plantings by the deadline established by the Zoning
Administrator at the time the deferral was granted, it will lead to
enforcement actions and shall be deemed a violation of the Ordinance. To
defer the installation of the required plant material, the owner or developer
shall be required to guarantee in cash.
d. Exceeding Required Plantings
i.
An applicant, upon the approval of the Zoning Administrator, may exceed
the number of required plantings.
ii. An applicant, upon the approval of the Zoning Administrator, may plant
shade trees for ornamental trees and/or large evergreen shrubberies for
medium evergreen shrubberies. However, the minimum number of
required plantings must be met.
e. Reducing Required Planting Size
i. The Zoning Administrator may allow for a reduced size for required
plantings, if it is in the best interest of the planting's survival and/or there
is a limitation of market availability. The Zoning Administrator may

1. A shade tree may be planted at a size of no less than four (4) feet in

An ornamental tree may be planted at a size of no less than three

3. A large evergreen shrub may be planted at a size of no less than a

C. MAINTENANCE OF REQUIRED LANDSCAPING
1. All vegetation that is required to be installed per the standards of this Section shall
be maintained in good condition. All dead or diseased vegetation shall be replaced
with healthy vegetation to maintain compliance with the Ordinance.
2.
Fences and walls that are installed to meet the requirements of this Section shall
be maintained in sound condition and shall be repaired or replaced when
damaged.
3. Preserved buffers shall remain in a natural, undisturbed, state. The removal of
dying or diseased vegetation is permitted, provided that an amount of vegetation
equivalent to a planted buffer of the same type remains in place along any one
hundred (100) foot length of buffer. Where buffer vegetation is removed or
destroyed, by any means, resulting in fewer plantings than required along any one
hundred (100) foot long section of buffer, the owner shall be required to
revegetate that area to bring it up to the minimum Planted Buffer standard.
D. STREET LANDSCAPING
1. Planting Area Standard
a. Street landscaping yards shall have a minimum depth of ten (10) feet, as
measured perpendicularly from the right-of-way toward the interior of the lot.
Street yards shall run the width of each street frontage (excluding driveways)
and shall be planted with live groundcover.
2. Required Vegetation
a. The following options are provided to meet the requirements for providing
vegetation within the planting area in Section 10.6.B (Plant Material
Standards):
i. Option One: One (1) shade tree shall be planted for each forty (40) linear
feet of street frontage, with a minimum of thirty (30) feet of separation
between each tree trunk.
ii. Option Two: One (1) ornamental tree shall be planted for each twenty (20)
linear feet of street frontage, with a minimum of fifteen (15) feet of
separation between each tree trunk.
iii. Option Three: Berms at least six (6) feet in height and have a slope not
exceeding 3:1. The berm must be permanently stabilized by adequate
vegetation. Berms shall not have a slope not exceeding 3:1.
b. The widths of driveways can be subtracted for the purposes of meeting the
tree spacing requirements.
10-5

E. INTERIOR PARKING LOT LANDSCAPING
1. The interior of each parking lot containing 40 or more spaces shall be landscaped
in accordance with the following standards, provided that those portions of off-
street parking areas that are used solely for the display of motor vehicles, boats,
agricultural equipment, and construction equipment shall be exempt from the
requirements of this Section.
a. Planting Islands
i. A planting island shall be installed at the end of each parking row (single
or double) and within the interior of each parking row at locations that
ensure that the distance between planting islands is no greater than one
hundred and ten (110) feet.
A. Minimum Area
1. Planting islands shall contain a minimum area of one hundred and
sixty (160) square feet for single row parking aisles and three
hundred and twenty (320) square feet for double row parking
aisles.
B. Required Plantings
1. One (1) shade tree shall be provided per single row planting island
and two (2) shade trees shall be provided per double row island.
b. Landscaped Medians
i. Double rows of parking containing forty-four (44) or more spaces on each
aisle shall be separated by a landscaped median, which shall be provided
in addition to the required planting islands.
A. Dimensions
1. Medians shall have a minimum width of six (6) feet and shall be
installed along the length of the parking aisle between the rows of
parking spaces, connecting the island at each end of the row.
B. Required Plantings
1. One (1) shade tree shall be provided for each forty (40) linear feet
of median, with a minimum of thirty (30) feet of separation
between each tree, as measured from the trunk.

D. BUFFER YARD STANDARDS
1. Buffer Yard Options
a. For each of the Buffer Yard types, there are three options for providing the
required buffer:
i. Undisturbed Natural Vegetated Buffer
A. Undisturbed natural vegetated buffers may be permitted as a buffering
option where sufficient natural low bushes, shrubs and trees exist to
provide the equivalent amount of screening that would be provided by
a Planted Buffer of the same type.
ii. Planted Buffer
A. A Planted Buffer may be utilized along property lines, or along
portions of property lines, where insufficient vegetation exists to meet
the standards for plantings for the type of required buffer, or where
vegetation will be removed as part of the development process.
iii. Barrier Buffer
A. A Barrier Buffer may be utilized, at the option of the property owner,
along property lines where a Planted Buffer would otherwise be
required, and where either insufficient width exists to provide the
planted buffer, or an additional barrier is desired.
2. Buffer Width Standards
a. The width standards shown in Table 10-2 shall apply to the various buffer
yard types, based on the selected option.
3. Buffer Planting Standards
a. All numerical references in the Table 10-2 (Required Buffer Standards) refer
to the number of plantings per 100 linear feet of buffer, or fraction thereof. All
installed vegetation shall meet the requirements of Section 10.6.B (Plant
Material Standards).
4. Barrier Standards
a. Materials
i. Barriers must be opaque and can include pre-treated wood fences, solid
vinyl fences, brick walls or berms. The finished side of the fence or wall
shall face the adjacent property. Altered chain link fences do not meet this
standard.
ii. The berm must be permanently stabilized by adequate vegetation. Berms
shall not have a slope of exceeding 3:1 and a height of at least six (6) feet.

SECTION 10.8: SITE FEATURE SCREENING
A. APPLICABILITY
1. The following requirements shall apply to site feature screening on Major or
Minor Site Plans. Detached Single-Family Dwellings, Two-Family Dwellings,
and Manufactured Homes on individual lots are to be excluded from the
requirements of this Section.
B. SITE FEATURES REQUIRED TO BE SCREENED
1. Solid Waste Collection Area Screening
a. Solid waste collection, trash compaction, recycling collection and similar
service areas shall be located behind the front building line of the principal
structure with which they are associated. In no case, may a solid waste
collection area be located within a required setback.
b. An opaque fence (wood or preassembled vinyl) or wall (brick or other
masonry, excluding smooth faced concrete block) with a minimum height of
six (6) feet shall be installed around solid waste collection areas, with gated
access provided on one side of the collection area. The materials and colors of
the fence or wall and gate(s) shall be compatible with the color and materials
of the building that the collection area serves.
C.
The use of chain link, or similar woven wire fencing with vinyl slats, fabric
coverings, or similar materials shall not be permitted as a method of screening
solid waste collection areas.

A. DRIVEWAY PERMITS AND INTERCONNECTION STANDARDS
1. These standards do not preclude the North Carolina Department of Transportation
driveway permit process and requirements.

traffic, individual parcels shall be permitted access to the street network in the
following manner:

minimum width of twenty (20) feet and shall be provided in a reasonable
manner.

interior drives and parking lots to provide cross access. It is recommended that

however, the parcel(s) which receive Site Plan approval earlier shall control
the exact location of the stubs.

SECTION 11.3: FPO (FLIGHT PATH OVERLAY DISTRICT)
A. PURPOSE
1. The purpose of the Flight Path Overlay District (FPO) is to promote the
compatible use of land in areas subject to frequent low-level military aviation
training operations.
B. PROHIBITED ACTIVITIES AND USES
1. The following uses of land and activities have been determined to be incompatible
with low level military aviation training operations and are prohibited within the
boundaries of the FPOD:
a. Any use, development or activity which produces smoke, dust, or other
airborne substances in such amounts as to impair pilot visibility or which
would otherwise interfere with the safe operation of aircraft;
b.
Any use, development or activity which produces light emissions or glare
either direct or indirect (reflective) - of such intensity and directed in such
directions as to impair pilot visibility or otherwise interfere with the safe
operation of aircraft; or
C.
Any use, development or activity which produces electromagnetic emissions
that interfere with navigation signals or radio communications between
aircraft and landing control facilities or with the aircraft's navigational or
communication equipment.
C. USES REQUIRING A SPECIAL USE PERMIT
1. The uses set forth in Table 11-1 below have been determined to be potentially
incompatible with low level military aviation training operations, and therefore
require additional review to determine whether they may be established or altered
within the FPO. Such uses may not be established or altered without the issuance
of a Special Use Permit in conformance with the standards of the procedures set
out in Section 4.10 (Special Use Permits).

ARTICLE 12 - - SIGN REGULATIONS
SECTION 12.1: GENERAL PROVISIONS
A. PERMITTING
1. Sign permits are required for all permanent signs.
2. Temporary signs do not require a permit; however they shall comply with the
standards in this Section.
B. DESIGN, CONSTRUCTION, AND MAINTENANCE
All signs shall be designed, constructed, and maintained in a manner to retain
sound structural condition, and shall comply with all applicable provision of the
North Carolina Building Code, all applicable electrical codes, and the provisions of
this Ordinance at all times.
C. EXEMPT SIGNS
1. Official signs installed by Onslow County, agencies of the State of North Carolina
and federal government agencies are exempt from the regulations established by
this Ordinance, provided that such signs are installed upon public property or
within a right-of-way owned or maintained by said governmental agency.
2. Signs required to be installed by any local, state, or federal rule, regulation or
ordinance may be displayed in accordance with the standard establishing their
size and placement. Examples of such signs include required building address
signs and fire safety signage.
D. SIGN DIMENSION COMPUTATIONS
1. The following standards shall control the computation of sign area and height:
a. The area of a sign shall be computed by means of the smallest square or
rectangle, that will encompass the extreme limits of the writing,
representation, emblem, or other display, together with any material or color
forming an integral part of the background of the display or used to
differentiate the sign from the backdrop or structure against which it is placed,
but not including any supporting framework, bracing, or decorative wall. See
Figure 12-1.
b. The sign area for a sign with more than one face shall be computed by adding
together the area of all sign faces visible from any one point.
C. The height of a freestanding sign shall be measured from the base of the sign
structure to the highest point of the sign structure. See Figure 12-2.

E. PROHIBITED SIGNS
1. The following are expressly prohibited:
a. Signs which obstruct clear sight distance at street intersections or otherwise
constitute a hazard to motorists or pedestrians.
b. Signs that are attached in any manner to the roof of a building or extend above
the leaves or parapet wall of a building.
12-2

C.
Signs placed within any portion of the right-of-way of a street or highway,
unless otherwise expressly authorized by this Ordinance or by statute.
d. Signs that obstruct fire escapes, windows, doors, or other openings used as
means of egress or required ventilation.
e. Motor vehicles, trailers, and similar conveyances parked with 100 feet of a
street's right-of-way that are used as a substitute for a permitted sign.
f. Signs shall not be affixed to poles, posts, stakes, on trees or other supporting
structures that are permanently installed or anchored into the ground through
the use of concrete foundations or similar anchoring techniques.
F. ELECTRONIC/DIGITAL CHANGEABLE COPY SIGNAGE
1. The necessary North Carolina Building Code electrical permits must be
completed. In addition, the following regulations shall apply to the display of any
electronic or digital changeable copy signage:
a. The sign copy/display shall not change or alternate more frequently than once
every 8 seconds.
b. The sign shall be designed and equipped to freeze in one position with no
more than the maximum allowable illumination if a malfunction occurs.
C. The sign shall not exceed a maximum illumination level of 0.3 foot candles
above ambient light, regardless of the method of illumination. The 0.3 foot
candles above ambient light shall be measured at a distance from the sign
equal to the following equation:
(Sign Area in square feet X 100)
d. Prior to permitting, the applicant shall submit a signed letter from the sign
manufacturer stating that the sign is equipped with the ability to comply with
the regulations in this section and will be programmed to do SO prior to
operation. The applicant shall also submit a signed letter from the sign owner
or operator stating that they have read the regulations in this section and will
not tamper with the manufacturer preset illumination settings.
G. ILLUMINATION
1.
All sign illumination must be downward facing, and/or arranged or shielded as to:
a. Not cast light above an imaginary line drawn at the top of the sign to avoid
negatively impacting air traffic whether commercial or private from Albert J.
Ellis Airport or airstrips, and/or military flights from the Marine Base Camp
Lejeune or Marine Air Station New River.
b. Avoid casting light upon adjacent properties and streets; and
C. Avoid casting light into the right-of-way creating a hazard for motor vehicles
and/or pedestrians.
H. SIGN FACE CHANGE OR REPAIR
1. If an applicant, proposes a sign face or cabinet change or sign repair where the
area of the sign and type of sign does not change, no new zoning permit is
required. However applicable building permits may apply.
2.
If the sign structure is being replaced, a new Zoning Permit shall be required, and
all standards shall apply.

SECTION 12.2: TEMPORARY SIGNS
A. COMMON STANDARDS
1.
All temporary signs shall comply with the following common standards:
a. Temporary signs shall not be placed within any public street right-of-way,
unless expressly permitted by this ordinance or the North Carolina General
Statutes. Signs placed in the right-of-way are subject to removal without
notice.
b. Temporary signs shall not be placed in a manner that obstructs clear site
distance for motorists at street intersections or driveways.
C. Temporary signs shall not be illuminated or be provided with any internal or
external electric source.
d. Temporary signs may be attached to exterior building walls and shall not be
placed in a manner that obstructs any door, fire sprinkler connection, or street
number sign. Only one (1) temporary sign attached to the exterior building
wall per street frontage. Temporary attached signs shall not exceed thirty-two
(32) square feet
e. Temporary signs shall not be placed on the roof of a building and any part of
the temporary sign shall not exceed the roof line.
B. FREESTANDING TEMPORARY SIGNS
1. Inflatable objects, festoons, streamers, pendants, feather banners, similar flags,
and any combination thereof may be displayed for no more than thirty (30)
consecutive days and for no more than sixty (60) days per calendar year.
2. Suspension of Type One (1) Freestanding Sign Regulations During Election
Season
a. Beginning on the thirtieth (30th) day prior to the beginning of early voting for
any scheduled primary or election, as established by the North Carolina Board
of Elections, and ending the tenth (10th) day following the primary or election,
the limit on the number of Type One (1) Freestanding Temporary Signs that
may be displayed per parcel is temporarily suspended. All other regulations
associated with such signage shall remain in effect during such period of
suspension unless otherwise permitted by State Law.
3. Type One (1) Freestanding Temporary Signs
a. Signs in this category consists of small, temporary "yard signs" that are
typically associated with the advertisement of real estate, construction
projects, and/or event announcements.
i. Where Permitted
A. Type One (1) Freestanding Temporary signs may be displayed in any
zoning district and may be associated with any use, including parcels
containing only vacant or undeveloped land. They are not permitted
within any street right-of-way.
ii. Number Permitted
A. One (1) Type One (1) Freestanding Temporary Sign may be displayed
per road frontage on an individual parcel.
iii. Permitted Size
A. The sign display area shall not exceed eight (8) square feet.
12-4

iv. Permitted Height
A. The maximum height of the sign, including any supporting posts or
stakes, is limited to five (5) feet above the adjacent grade.
V. Sign Material
A. The display area (sign face) shall be composed of a rigid material.
vi. Mounting Standards
A. Signs may only be mounted and supported by posts or stakes.
vii. Permitted Duration of Display
A. When associated with an event, these signs should be removed no later
than 21 days after the completion, closing or date of the event.
4. Type Two (2) Freestanding Temporary Signs
a. Signs in this category are generally referred to as "banners" and are typically
associated with the announcement of community, sporting and similar special
events as well as "grand openings" and special sale events for commercial
establishments.
i. Where Permitted
A. Type Two (2) Freestanding Temporary signs may be displayed in any
zoning district and may be associated with any use, including parcels
containing only vacant or undeveloped land. They are not permitted
within any street right-of-way.
ii. Number Permitted
A. One Type Two (2) Freestanding Temporary Sign may be displayed per
individual parcel. One additional sign shall be permitted for each road
frontage.
iii. Permitted Size
A. The sign display area shall not exceed thirty-two (32) square feet.
iv. Permitted Duration of Display
A. Type Two (2) signs are permitted to be displayed for a maximum
period of thirty (30) calendar days. A maximum of six (6) separate
displays are permitted during each calendar year with a minimum of
fourteen (14) days of separation between displays.
5. Type Three (3) Freestanding Temporary Signs
a. Signs in this category are large temporary signs typically associated with the
advertisement of large tracts of land for sale, construction, and development
activity or the advertisement of commercial or industrial buildings for sale or
lease.
i. Permitted Size
A. The maximum permitted sign area is sixty-four (64) square feet.
ii. Permitted Height
A. The maximum height of the sign, including any supporting posts or
stakes, shall not exceed twelve (12) feet above the adjacent grade.
iii. Number Permitted
A. One (1) Type Three (3) Freestanding Temporary Sign may be
displayed per road frontage on an individual parcel.
iv. Sign Material
12-5

A. The display area (sign face) shall be composed of a rigid material,
such as treated wood or metal.
V. Permitted Duration of Display
A. Type Three (3) signs may be displayed without a time limit upon any
parcel which contains only vacant or undeveloped land, provided that
such signs shall be removed or repaired in circumstances where the
sign face(s) and/or supporting structures deteriorates or suffers
damage.
SECTION 12.3: PERMANENT SIGNS
A. WALL SIGNS
1. Where Permitted
a. Wall signs shall be permitted to be displayed in association with any
nonresidential use in any zoning district.
2. Number of Signs Permitted
a. One (1) wall sign shall be permitted per building wall for single tenant
buildings. Buildings containing multiple tenant spaces with individual exterior
entrances may display one (1) wall sign per tenant space at the tenant
entrance; other walls shall be permitted to have one wall sign.
3. Canopy Signage (i.e., Gas Station Canopies)
a. One sign, not exceeding ten percent (10%) of the face of a canopy, may be
displayed per face of a freestanding or attached canopy structure. Canopy
signage are not to extend above the structure's roof line.
4. Permitted Sign Area
a. The maximum permitted area of wall sign(s) per building wall shall be one
square foot per linear foot of the building wall. No sign face area may exceed
two-hundred (200) square feet.
5. Illumination
a. Wall signs may be illuminated either internally or externally.
6. Mounting Requirements
a. Wall signs may not project more than twelve (12) inches from the building
wall to which they are mounted and shall not be mounted in a manner where
any part of the sign extends past the top of the parapet / building wall or
leaves.
B. FREESTANDING SIGNS
1. Sign Placement
a. No portion of a freestanding sign shall be closer than five (5) feet from any
property line.
b.
Residential development signs may be placed within the right-of-way with
authorization from NCDOT.
C.
Signs shall not be located in a manner which would obstruct the sight distance
of any street or driveway intersection.
2. Number of Signs Permitted
a. Nonresidential Use on an Individual Parcel
i.
One (1) freestanding sign may be displayed per street front provided that
signs are separated by a minimum of 300 feet.
b. Nonresidential Uses (Multiple Tenants) on One (1) Property
12-6

i. One freestanding multi-unit sign per street frontage shall be permitted.
ii. Each freestanding multi-unit sign shall be located on separate street
frontages.
iii. A single tenant shall not use all the permitted sign area allowed.
C. Residential Developments
i. Freestanding signs associated with a residential development shall be
limited to one double faced sign or two single-faced signs per street
entrance.
ii. The area of the sign face shall not exceed sixty-four (64) square feet. The
height may not exceed twenty (20) feet.
iii. These signs may be placed within the right-of-way with authorization
from NCDOT.
3. Area and Height Limitations
a. HB, L-IN, and H-IN Districts
i.
For parcels with buildings containing up to fifty-thousand (50,000) square
feet of gross floor area, the maximum sign area for a freestanding sign
shall be eighty (80) square feet. For each additional ten-thousand (10,000)
square feet of gross floor area, an additional ten (10) square feet of sign
area is permitted, up to a maximum of one-hundred and fifty (150) square
feet of sign area.
ii. The maximum permitted height of freestanding signs in these districts
shall be twenty (20) feet.
b. OI and CB Districts
i.
For parcels with buildings containing up to ten-thousand (10,000) square
feet of gross floor area, the maximum sign area shall be sixty-four (64)
square feet. For each additional ten-thousand (10,000) square feet of gross
floor area, and additional eight (8) square feet of sign area is permitted, up
to a maximum of one-hundred (100) square feet of sign area.
A. The maximum permitted height of freestanding signs in these districts
shall be fifteen (15) feet.
C.
All Other Districts
i. The maximum sign area shall be thirty-six (36) square feet.
ii. The maximum permitted height of signs in these districts shall be ten (10)
feet.
C. INCIDENTAL SIGNS
1. Entrance Drive Signage
a. One (1) sign, not exceeding four (4) square feet in area, may be displayed on
each side of the street entrance to the parking area or internal driveway
network of a nonresidential use.
b. Such signs shall not exceed three (3) feet in height and shall be located with
ten (10) feet of the intersection.
2. Drive Through Service Signage
a. Signage associated with drive-through services may be displayed immediately
adjacent to a drive through service lane.
b. Such signs shall be oriented to face the drive through service lane and shall
not contribute to the overall sign square footage of a site.
12-7

c. Drive Through Service Signs shall not exceed eight (8) feet in height.
SECTION 12.4: MASTER SIGN PLANS
A. PURPOSE
1. The purpose of the Master Sign Plan is to provide an alternative to the permanent
signage criteria contained within this Article while encouraging innovation,
creative, attractive, and effective signage.
B. ARCHITECTURAL THEME
1. Signage proposed as a part of the Master Sign Plan shall be architecturally
integrated with the building design and/or site using similar and coordinated
design features and materials. Specifically, proposed signage must satisfy the
following criteria:
a. Freestanding Signs:
i. Structural aspects of signs, such as poles, supports, and cabinets, shall be
constructed of materials and colors related to the principal building.
ii. The text or sign copy of freestanding signs shall be limited to the name
and/or logo of the business/establishment and the street address only
(except for fuel-pricing signs).
b. Wall (Attached) Signs:
i. No power supply shall be visible from pedestrian areas, parking areas, or
streets.
ii. In shopping centers, each establishment's sign(s) shall be centered
horizontally over the storefront and/or entrance(s).
iii. No sign shall extend above the building roof line.
C. Awning Signs:
i. The shape, design, and color of awnings shall be carefully designed to
coordinate with, and not dominate, the architectural style of the building.
Where multiple awnings are used on the building and/or site, the design
and color of the sign awnings and all other awnings shall be coordinated.
ii. The signage text and/or logo shall be located only on the valance of the
awning itself.
iii. Sign copy text shall be limited to the name of the business and/or the
business logo.
C. APPLICATION REQUIREMENTS
1. The Master Sign Plan application shall include a signage plan including the
following:
a. A site plan identifying the locations of all proposed signs.
b.
A list of each type of sign proposed to be allowed within the development. At
a minimum, the following information will be provided:
i. Freestanding sign standards to include dimensions of and materials used in
support structures, dimensions of sign face, maximum individual and
aggregate sign area per establishment and maximum height of sign.
ii. Wall (Attached) Sign standards to include maximum individual and
aggregate sign area per establishment and maximum area in relation to
storefront area.
iii. Directional sign standards to include height and sign face area.

iv. Illumination guidelines describing the type(s) proposed, placement,
intensity, and hours of illumination.
V. Changeable copy guidelines.
vi. Temporary sign guidelines.
vii. Theme and color guidelines to include graphic depictions of sign designs,
color palettes, font style, letter size, illumination, materials, and sample
copy areas.

SECTION 12.5: OUTDOOR ADVERTISING (BILLBOARD) SIGN
A. APPLICABILITY
1. Outdoor Advertising Signs shall be permitted only in the RA, HB, L-IN, and H-
IN districts as either a principal use or secondary use on a parcel.
2. Outdoor Advertising Signs are subject to any applicable North Carolina
Department of Transportation standards.
B. STANDARDS FOR OUTDOOR ADVERTISING SIGNS
1. No portion shall be closer than five (5) feet from any property line.
2. The maximum sign face area shall be 450 square feet.
3. Outdoor Advertising Signs shall not be mounted to a building or any other
occupiable structure.
4. The maximum permitted height shall be fifty (50) feet.
5. Each side of the sign shall have only one (1) sign display area. "Double-decker"
signs with signs erected one (1) over or above the other and side-by-side signs
with signs erected one next to the other are prohibited.
6. Signs shall be a minimum of five hundred (500) feet from any park, school,
church, and/or navigable body of water; and shall be a minimum of two hundred
and fifty (250) from any residential structure.
7. Each sign shall be a minimum of one-thousand (1,000) feet from any other off-
premise outdoor advertising sign. The distance shall be measured radially from
the nearest point of the proposed sign location to the nearest point of the existing
sign location.
8. Changeable copy shall be permitted on outdoor advertising signs, provided that
electronic or digital changeable copy signs shall comply with the standards of
Section 12.1(F).
9. Outdoor Advertising Signs may be illuminated internally or externally, provided
that pole mounted signs shall have their means of illumination affixed directly to
the sign structure where external illumination is provided.
